newsitem.title: USA: Heinz ends talks for Bumble Bee tuna.
newsitem.headline: Heinz ends talks for Bumble Bee tuna.

text.p: H.J. Heinz Co. said Wednesday it has ended talks to acquire the production plants of Bumble Bee tuna from Bumble Bee Seafoods Inc., a unit of Unicord Public Co. Ltd. of Bangkok.

A statement by Heinz and Questor Partners Fund LP, an investor group, did not explain why discussions were halted. But analysts said the potential purchase, valued at more than $200 million, was under close scrutiny by the Federal Trade Commission.
Heinz officials were not available for comment.

Analysts said a merger would have given the Pittsburgh-based food giant, which owns Star-Kist tuna, too much market share. Star-Kist tuna already is the world's leading tuna producer in terms of sales.

Analyst Laurie Feldman at Bear Stearns said Heinz decided to terminate discussions after receiving a "second request for information from the FTC." She said she did not know when the company received that request.
"Had (Heinz) purchased just the supply rights, they would have had 85 percent of all the tuna volume in the world, said Feldman. "That's just too much."
Had the transaction gone through, Questor would have purchased Bumble Bee tuna, and in turn would have sold its three production plants to Heinz.
Heinz's stock fell 37.5 cents to $35.75 on the New York Stock Exchange shortly before midday.
